lesson.name: Lesson 1.8 Choosing the Correct Variable to Solve For, Part 1

page.title: 1.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will manipulate equations and solve for a variable. You will also begin to determine which forms of equations are more useful than others.  

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Solve for a particular variable, given an equation.
  • Determine the more useful form of an equation.
  • Explain the phrase ‚Äúto solve for a variable.‚Äù

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.8.1: Expressing Relationships Between Two Quantities 
  • 1.8.2: Identifying the Most Useful Form of an Equation 
  • 1.8.2: Self Check 
  • 1.8.3: Writing Equations and Isolating Variables 
  • 1.8.3: Self Check 
  • 1.8.4: Writing Equations Given Dimensions of Shapes

After that, you‚Äôll practice and review.

  • 1.8.5: Practice
  • 1.8.6 Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.8.1: Expressing Relationships Between Two Quantities
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

The table shows the relationship between the base length, ùëè, and the area, ùê¥, of some parallelograms. All the parallelograms have the same height. Base length is measured in inches, and area is measured in square inches. Complete the table by entering the missing information.


\(ùëè\)
\(b\) (inches)

\(ùê¥\)
\(A\) (square inches)

\(1\)

\(3\)

\(2\)

\(6\)

\(3\)

\(9\)

\(4.5\)

\(A\;=\;?\)
 \( \frac{11}{2} \)

\(B\;=\;?\)

\(C\;=\;?\)

\(36\)

\(D\;=\;?\)

\(46.5\)

Enter your answer for \(A\)

\( A= 13.5 \)


Enter your answer for \(B\)

\( B= \frac{33}{2} \)


Enter your answer for \(C\)

\( C= 12 \)


Enter your answer for \(D\)

\( D= 15.5 \)

page.title: 1.8.2: Identifying the Most Useful Form of an Equation
page.contents:
Activity

After a parade, a group of volunteers is helping to pick up the trash along a 2-mile stretch of a road.

The group decides to divide the length of the road so that each volunteer is responsible for cleaning up equal-length sections.


1. Find the length of a road section for each volunteer if there are the following numbers of volunteers. Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.

a. 8 volunteers

\( \frac{1}{4}\ \) mile


b. 10 volunteers

\( \frac{1}{5}\ \) mile


c. 25 volunteers

\( \frac{2}{25}\ \) mile or \( 0.08 \) mile


d. 36 volunteers

\( \frac{2}{36}\ \) or \( \frac{1}{18}\ \) mile


2. Write an equation that would make it easy to find the length \( ‚Ñì \), in miles, of a road section for each volunteer, if there are \( ùëõ \) volunteers.

\( l=\frac{2}{n} \)

3. Find the number of volunteers in the group if each volunteer cleans up a section of the following lengths. Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.

a. 0.4 mile

5 volunteers


b. \( \frac{2}{7} \) mile

7 volunteers


c. 0.125 mile

16 volunteers


d. \( \frac{6}{45}\ \) mile

15 volunteers


4. Write an equation that would make it easy to find the number of volunteers, \( ùëõ \), if each volunteer cleans up a section that is \( ‚Ñì \) miles.

\( n= \frac{2}{l} \)


Extending Your Thinking

Let's think about the graph of the equation \( y=\frac{2}{x} \).


1. Make a table of \( (ùë•,ùë¶) \) pairs that will help you graph the equation. Make sure to include some negative numbers for \( ùë• \) and some numbers that are not integers.

\( ùë• \)

\( ùë¶ \)

A.

F.

 B.

G.

 C.

H. 

 D.

I.


Sample Answer A =2.5, B= -1, C=0.5, D=1.25, F= 0.8, G= -2, H=4, I= 1.6.

2. Plot the graph on the coordinate axes. You may need to find a few more points to plot to make the graph look smooth.

 

Correct graph:


  


3. The coordinate plane provided is too small to show the whole graph. What do you think the graph looks like when \( ùë• \) is between \( 0 \) and \( \frac{1}{2} \)? Try some values of \( ùë• \) to test your idea.

Sample response: The graph gets steeper and steeper as \( ùë• \) gets closer to 0.


4. What is the largest value that \( ùë¶ \) can ever be?

Sample response: There is no limit to the value of \( ùë¶ \).

page.title: 1.8.2: Self Check
page.contents: Use formula for the area of a triangle, \( A=\frac{1}{2}bh \), where \( b \) is the base of the triangle and \( h \) is the height of the triangle. Which equation would best be used to find the base of the triangle?

answer.response: That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: To find the base, solve for \( b \). Multiply both sides by 2 then divide both sides by h. Now, \( b=\frac{2A}{h} \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Since \( b \) stands for the base in the formula, solve the formula for \( b \). The answer is \( b=\frac{2A}{h} \)}.
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Since \( b \) stands for the base in the formula, solve the formula for \( b \). The answer is \( b=\frac{2A}{h} \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Since \( b \) stands for the base in the formula, solve the formula for \( b \). The answer is \( b=\frac{2A}{h} \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.8.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solve a Formula for a Specific Variable

We have all probably worked with some geometric formulas in our study of mathematics. Formulas are used in so many fields, it is important to recognize formulas and be able to manipulate them easily.

It is often helpful to solve a formula for a specific variable. If you need to put a formula in a spreadsheet, it is not unusual to have to solve it for a specific variable first. We isolate that variable on one side of the equal sign with a coefficient of 1, and all other variables and constants are on the other side of the equal sign.

Geometric formulas often need to be solved for another variable, too. The formula \( V= \frac{1}{3} œÄrh^2h \) is used to find the volume of a right circular cone when given the radius of the base and height. In the next example, we will solve this formula for the height.

Example

Solve the formula  \( V= \frac{1}{3} œÄrh^2h \)  for \( h \).

Write the formula
Remove the fraction on the right
Simplify
Divide both sides by  \( œÄr^2 \)


We could now use this formula to find the height of a right circular cone when we know the volume and the radius of the base, by using the formula \( h= \frac{3V}{œÄr^2} \) .

In the sciences, we often need to change temperature from Fahrenheit to Celsius or vice versa. If you travel in a foreign country, you may want to change the Celsius temperature to the more familiar Fahrenheit temperature.

Example

Solve the formula  \( C = \frac{5}{9} ( F ‚àí 32 ) \)  for \( F \).

Solution

Write the formula.
Remove the fraction on the right.
Simplify.
Add 32 to both sides.

You can now use the formula   \( C = \frac{9}{5}C + 32 \)    to find the Fahrenheit temperature when we know the Celsius temperature.

Sometimes we might be given an equation that is solved for \( y \) and need to solve it for \( x \), or vice versa. In the following example, we‚Äôre given an equation with both \( x \) and \( y \) on the same side and we‚Äôll solve it for \( y \).

Example

Solve the formula  \( 8x + 7y = 15 \)  for \( y \).

Solution

We will isolate \( y \) on one side of the equation.
Subtract  \(6x \)  from both sides to isolate the term with \( y \).
Simplify.
Divide both sides by 7 to make the coefficient of \( y \) one.
Simplify.

Try It: Solve a Formula for a Specific Variable


Solve \( 8x+ 7y =15 for x \). 

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve this equation for \( x \).

Original Equation

\( 8x+ 7y =15 \)

Subtract \( 7y \) from each side.

\( 8x+ 7y -7y =15 -7y \)

Simplify.

\( 8x =15-7y \)

Divide both sides by 8.

  \( \frac{8x}{8}=\frac{15-7y}{8} \)

The equation solved for \( x \) is \( x=\frac{15}{8}-\frac{7y}{8} \).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.8.3: Self Check
page.contents: A pool is filled with 15,000 gallons of water. It loses 200 gallons per day. How many days, \( d \), have passed when the pool has \( g \) gallons of water?

answer.response: That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: To find how many days it takes to get to \( g \) gallons, solve \( g=15,000-200d \), for \( d \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: This represents the number of gallons in the pool. Write an expression to find the days. The answer is \( \frac{15,000-g}{200} \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Be sure to include that the pool started with 15,000 gallons. The answer is \( \frac{15,000-g}{200} \).
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Be sure to include that the pool started with 15,000 gallons. The answer is \( \frac{15,000-g}{200} \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.8.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For 1-4 use the problem below:
Priya is buying raisins and almonds to make trail mix. Almonds cost $5.20 per pound and raisins cost $2.75 per pound. Priya spent $11.70 buying almonds and raisins. The relationship between pounds of almonds, pounds of raisins, and the total cost is represented by the equation 5.2a+2.75r=11.7.

How many pounds of raisins did Priya buy if she bought the following amount of almonds:

  1. 2 pounds of almonds

Correct! 0.473

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0.473. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. 1.06 pounds of almonds

Correct! 2.25

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2.25. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. 0.64 pounds of almonds

Correct! 3.044

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3.044. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. a pounds of almonds

Correct! \(r=\frac{1.7-5.2a}{2.75}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(r=\frac{11.7-5.2a}{2.75}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For 5 and 6 use the problem below:
A car traveled 180 miles at a constant rate.

5. For each of the missing spaces in the table, a-d, Select the missing value that completes the table to show the rate at which the car was traveling if it completed the same distance in each number of hours.

travel time
(hours)

rate of travel
(miles per hour)

5
  1.  _____

4.5
  1.  _____

3
  1.  _____

2.25
  1.  _____

   a.______

Correct!

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 36. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


   b. _____

Correct!

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 40. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


   c. _____

Correct!

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 60. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


   d. _____

Correct!

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 80. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


6. Choose the equation that would make it easy to find the rate at which the car was traveling in miles per hour r, if it traveled for t hours.

Correct! \(r=\frac{180}t\)

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(r=\frac{180}t\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Bananas cost $0.50 each, and apples cost $1.00 each. Select all the combinations of bananas and apples that Elena could buy for exactly $3.50.

Correct! 3 bananas and 2 apples,1 banana and 3 apples, 5 bananas and 1 apple

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are 3 bananas and 2 apples,1 banana and 3 apples, 5 bananas and 1 apple. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


8. Choose the best answer to solve the formula \(A=P+Prt\) for t.

Correct! \(t=\frac{A-P}{Pr}\)

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(t=\frac{A-P}{Pr}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.8.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Choosing Which Equation to Use

A relationship between quantities can be described in more than one way. Some ways are more helpful than others, depending on what we want to find out. Let's look at the angles of an isosceles triangle, for example.


The two angles near the horizontal side have equal measurement in degrees, \( a \).

The sum of angles in a triangle is 180¬∞, so the relationship between the angles can be expressed as:

\( a+a+b=180 \)

Suppose we want to find a when \( b \) is 20¬∞.

Let's substitute 20 for \( b \) and solve the equation. 

\( a+a+b=180 \)
\( 2a+20=180 \)
\( 2a=180-20 \)
\( 2a=160 \)

\( a=80 \)

What is the value of \( b \) if a is 72.5¬∞?

\( a+a+b=180 \)
\( 72.5+72.5+b=80 \)
\( 145+b=180 \)
\( b=35 \)

Notice that when \( b \) is given, we did the same calculation repeatedly to find \( a: we substituted b into the first equation, subtracted \( b from 180, and then divided the result by 2.

Instead of taking these steps over and over whenever we know \( b \) and want to find \( a \), we can rearrange the equation to isolate \( a \):

\( a+a+b=180 \)
\( 2a+b=180 \)
\( 2a=180-b \)
\( a=\frac{180-b}{2} \)
\( a=90-\frac{1}{2}b \)

This equation is equivalent to the first one. To find \( a \), we can now simply substitute any value of \( b \) into this equation and evaluate the expression on the right side.

Likewise, we can write an equivalent equation to make it easier to find \( b \) when we know \( a \):

\( a+a+b=180 \)
\( 2a+b=180 \)
\( b=180-2a \)

Rearranging an equation to isolate one variable is called solving for a variable. In this example, we have solved for \( a \) and for \( b \). All three equations are equivalent. Depending on what information we have and what we are interested in, we can choose a particular equation to use.

Try It: Choosing Which Equation to Use

Jake and Bryce are saving their allowance. Jake saved for one week and Bryce saved for 2 weeks. Together they saved $15. Write an equation to find Bryce‚Äôs allowance.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write an equation to find Bryce‚Äôs allowance.

Let \( j \): Jake‚Äôs allowance and \( b \): Bryce‚Äôs allowance.

\( j + 2b = 15 \)

Solve for \( b \) to find Bryce‚Äôs allowance.

Original Equation

\( j + 2b = 15 \)

Subtract j from each side.

\( j - j + 2b = 15-j \)

Simplify.

\( 2b=15-j \)

Divide both sides by 2.

  \( \frac{2b}{2}=\frac{15-j}{2} \)
So to find Bryce‚Äôs allowance, use the equation: \( b=\frac{15-j}{2} \) or \( b=\frac{15}{2}-\frac{j}{2} \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.8.3: Writing Equations and Isolating Variables
page.contents:
Activity

1. Tank A initially contained 124 liters of water. It is then filled with more water, at a constant rate of 9 liters per minute. How many liters of water are in Tank A after the following amounts of time have passed?

a. 4 minutes
b. 80 seconds
c. \( m \) minutes

Enter your answers here.

Check your answers. The corresponding values are:

a.1 60
b. 136
c. \( 124 + 9m \)


Video: Isolating the Variable

Watch the following video to further explore the above situation.



2. How many minutes, \(m\), have passed when Tank A contains the following amounts of water?

a. 151 liters
b. 191.5 liters
c. 270.25 liters
d. \( p \) liters

Enter your answers here.

Check your answers. The corresponding values are:

a. 3 or \( m=3 \)
b. 7.5
c. 16.25
d. \( \frac{p-124}{9} \)


3. Tank B, which initially contained 80 liters of water, is being drained at a rate of 2.5 liters per minute. How many liters of water remain in the tank after the following amounts of time?

a. 30 seconds
b. 7 minutes
c. \( t \) minutes

Enter your answers here.

Check your answers. The corresponding values are:

a. 78.75
b. 2.5
c. \( 80 - 2.5t \)


4. For how many minutes, \( t \), has the water been draining when Tank B contains the following amounts of water?

Enter your answer here.

Check your answers. The corresponding values are:

a. 2
b. 19
c. 24.8
d. \( \frac{80-v}{2.5} \)

page.title: 1.8.4: Writing Equations Given Dimensions of Shapes
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The perimeter of a rectangle is 48 centimeters. The relationship between the length, the width, and the perimeter of the rectangle can be described with the equation: \( 2 \cdot \text{length} +2 \cdot \text{width}=48 \).

Find the length, in centimeters, if the width is:

1. 10 centimeters

Correct Answer: 14


2. 3.6 centimeters

Correct Answer: 20.4


3. \( w \) centimeters

Correct Answer: \( \frac{48-2W}{2} \) or \( 24-w \)

page.title: 1.8.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Solve for a particular variable, given an equation.
  • Determine the more useful form of an equation.
  • Explain the phrase ‚Äúto solve for a variable.‚Äù

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.8.1: Expressing Relationships Between Two Quantities
    • In this activity, you completed a table by using the relationship between the values already in the table.
  • 1.8.2: Identifying the Most Useful Form of an Equation
    • In this activity, you worked to recognize the most useful form of an equation. You also wrote an equation in the most useful form that would be needed to find specific information.
  • 1.8.2: Self Check 
  • 1.8.3: Writing Equations and Isolating Variables
    • In this activity, you used equations to solve for specific variables that helped answer questions about given situations. 
  • 1.8.3: Self Check 
  • 1.8.4: Writing Equations Given Dimensions of Shapes
    • In this activity, you found the length of a rectangle given the perimeter as well as the width as both a constant and a variable.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.8.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you‚Äôve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
